image.altText: The name "Albermarle" lettered on the side of a building.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of workers are expected to lose their jobs at Albemarle's Kemerton lithium plant as the miner responds to further volatility in the global market.

title.children: 300 jobs to be lost as US lithium giant makes further cuts at WA plant

image.altText: SES tape on a tree

props.synopsis: Two people have been killed by a falling tree hitting their car as wild storms lashed the southern part of the state.

title.children: Two people killed by falling tree as storms lash WA

image.altText: A blue screen on computer screens in a newsroom

props.synopsis: From the blue screen of death, to a very lucky pup — the ABC's photographers were on hand to capture WA in all its glory throughout the month of July.

title.children: Heartbreak, a global computer meltdown and a brave puppy define WA's best images for July

image.altText: A crowd waving green, red and y ellow flags surround a truck bearing a large picture of a white-bearded man.

props.synopsis: Iran's supreme leader vows vengeance for the strike that killed Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh, who has been farewelled by thousands in a funeral procession in Doha.

title.children: Hamas leader mourned as Iran's allies expected in Tehran to discuss retaliation

image.altText: A construction crew working on a home build on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: As hundreds of West Australians wait for Ronnie Michel-Elhaj's failing building company Nicheliving to finish their homes, his wife's luxury build continues.

title.children: Building firm Nicheliving has been deregistered, but luxury home build of company boss's wife continues apace

image.altText: American gymnastics superstar Simone Biles balances on a beam on one foot while sweeping her other leg out.

props.synopsis: Australian teenager Ruby Pass is in the artistic gymnastics all-around final, competing alongside US superstars Simone Biles and Sunisa Lee. Follow live.

title.children: Australian Ruby Pass in all-around gymnastics final against Olympics legend Simone Biles

image.altText: A middle-aged woman stands with her arms folded.

props.synopsis: Parents at Cooinda Primary School in WA's South West say staff at the school's specialist learning program lacked the required training to supervise their children.

title.children: Shocked parents say students with learning disabilities left to fend for themselves

image.altText: Two men in suits, Craig Challen and Richard Harris, stand at a podium in front of Scott Morrison. Two awards sit in front

props.synopsis: For three years in a row, James Dawkins and his old high school mate thought they were on a winning streak — until authorities took notice.

title.children: How a three-year gambling streak on Australian of the Year led authorities to a postal worker

image.altText: Three Australia men's hockey players converge in celebration, pumping their fists, after scoring a goal

props.synopsis: Australia's men's hockey team has booked themselves a quarterfinal berth after hammering New Zealand in Paris, while both Australia's women's basketball teams enjoyed victories on day six of the Olympics.

title.children: Kookaburras earn quarterfinal berth, Opals rediscover their lustre, Gangurrus sink the US in Paris

image.altText: A sketch drawing shows a teenage boy with his head in his hands. He is sitting next to three men.

props.synopsis: The teenager suspected to have killed three children in Southport, England on Monday has been named.

title.children: Teenage Southport murder suspect named after three children killed

image.altText: Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan in separate images. Both are held behind clear screens.

props.synopsis: Türkiye confirms it is coordinating a major international prisoner swap involving citizens of Belarus, Germany, Norway, Poland, Slovenia, Russia and the US. They include Americans Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan, who the US says were wrongfully detained in Russia.

title.children: Journalist Evan Gershkovich, ex-marine Paul Whelan released as part of major global prisoner swap

image.altText: Close up image of new shoots growing from a tree stump

props.synopsis: Eight new shoots appear on the stump of a famous tree that was illegally felled in northern England last year.

title.children: Famous Sycamore Gap tree illegally cut down showing signs of life

image.altText: A walker competes with the Eiffel Tower in the background

props.synopsis: The sheer brutality of the conditions ensured the race walk would be a war of attrition. Every finisher is worth their weight in gold.

title.children: The impossible brutality of a walk in Paris

image.altText: A man wearing a green shirt sits in ablue chair and looks out

props.synopsis: The Matildas are on the lookout for a new head coach after Football Australia ended months of speculation and confirmed Tony Gustavsson's contract would not be extended.

title.children: Gustavsson era over as Matildas hunt for new coach

image.altText: Three women at a social function.

props.synopsis: When Jade Gregory moved to a beautiful but isolated WA town, she struggled to connect with others. Now, she's bringing local women together.

title.children: How do you make friends when moving to a new town?

image.altText: Close-up shot of Matt Wright's side profile as he walks into Darwin Local Court wearing a light blue shirt.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for the celebrity crocodile wrangler have indicated he will plead not guilty to perverting the course of justice in relation to the aftermath of a fatal chopper crash, ahead of a potential jury trial in the NT Supreme Court.

title.children: Netflix star Matt Wright set to plead not guilty to perverting the course of justice

image.altText: A composite image showing Linday Reynolds on the left and Brittany Higgins on the right

props.synopsis: With mediation attempts and extensions of olive branches falling flat, Senator Linda Reynolds's defamation trial against Brittany Higgins and her partner David Sharaz will kick off tomorrow.

title.children: The very public spat between Brittany Higgins and Linda Reynolds is about to be heard in court, and there's a lot at stake

image.altText: Ali Khamenei sits in a chair and speaks with Ismail Haniyeh and Ziad Nakhaleh, who sit on a nearby couch in a formal room.

props.synopsis: Specifics about how Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr were killed on Tuesday are scarce, but one thing is certain: the two high-profile hits will further destabilise the Middle East.

title.children: Two global assassination plots in 24 hours: Is this the day that changes the Middle East?

image.altText: Tony Burke in focus standing next to Anthony Albanese out of focus

props.synopsis: Labor is well aware that there are no shortage of headaches to contend with as the election looms. But can Anthony Albanese's cabinet reshuffle lessen the pain?

title.children: Albanese's cabinet reshuffle was akin to shaking a snow globe — the pieces are the same but slightly rearranged

image.altText: A bronze statue of a woman smiling.

props.synopsis: Susan Ryan was the first female Labor minister and the first female minister for women during her career as part of the Hawke government in the 1980s.

title.children: Statue of late senator Susan Ryan, who championed women in politics, unveiled in Canberra

image.altText: A post-impressionist painting of a green field with farmhouses behind, three with red roofs and one with a blue roof.

props.synopsis: The blue roof, or Farm at Le Pouldu, by post-impressionist Paul Gauguin is purchased by the National Gallery of Australia, making it the first of his paintings to enter an Australian public collection.

title.children: National Gallery of Australia spends $9.8 million on painting by controversial artist Paul Gauguin

image.altText: Foreign minister Penny Wong faces the media in Adelaide. 2024-04-06 10:04:00

props.synopsis: Australians have been urged to leave Lebanon immediately as the foreign minister emphasises the Beirut airport could close if the situation worsens.

title.children: Foreign Minister Penny Wong warns Australians in Lebanon to leave immediately

image.altText: A view over someone's shoulder of an Indigenous woman with glasses, half-smiling

props.synopsis: The Waanyi writer has won the $60,000 Miles Franklin Literary Award for her epic novel Praiseworthy, a fabulist critique of colonisation and climate change.

title.children: Alexis Wright becomes the first person to win the Miles Franklin and the Stella Prize in the same year

image.altText: Alanna Kennedy of Australia reacts after losing to the USA during the Paris Olympic Games

props.synopsis: After three underwhelming performances saw them crash out at the group stage for the first time since 2000, the Matildas' Olympic campaign must be a reality check for the Australian game.

title.children: Matildas' Olympic exit is the reality check Australia has been bracing for

image.altText: A selfie of a smiling young woman reclined on a leather sofa, by a dog resting it's head on her shoulder.

props.synopsis: At the end of 2020, counsellor Caroline Kell hit a breaking point. She asked herself, "do I want to continue to live my life like this?" The answer was no.

title.children: 'Reformed busy person' Caroline Kell on cherishing the small moments

image.altText: Two women pose together in a tight shot.

props.synopsis: Some Olympic battles are fought between nations on the mat. Others, it seems, are fought on social media between teammates. This is the story of the latter.

title.children: Explaining the Biles-Skinner social media beef, team F.A.A.F.O, and 'the golden girls'

image.altText: Menstruation products

props.synopsis: More than 60 per cent of girls, women, and gender-diverse people who menstruate are struggling to buy basic period products amid soaring costs of living, Australia's largest body of data on periods has found.

title.children: Unable to afford $15 a month, menstruating people are being forced to make do without period products

image.altText: A man in a store, wearing a cap and bumbag.

props.synopsis: The FBI, AFP and Malaysian police have all failed to charge Adrian Katong. In the meantime the phishing syndicate operator is leading a life of luxury and becoming more brazen in his operations that have taken millions of dollars from Australians.

title.children: Adrian Katong ran a one-stop shop for phishing scams. Here's how he was tracked down

image.altText: A black sign with 'CFMEU Victoria' written on it, hanging on a construction site.

props.synopsis: The application could reach the Federal Court as early as this afternoon.

title.children: Fair Work set to apply for CFMEU administrators as crossbenchers tell federal government to go further

image.altText: An aerial view of a spectacular tropical coastline.

props.synopsis: From bird flu to the Japanese encephalitis virus, the threat from Australia's north is increasing and authorities need you on the front line.

title.children: Biosecurity fears on the rise as end of winter looms

image.altText: A man in a suit sitting and speaking, with his arms raised, gesturing

props.synopsis: Donald Trump uses an appearance at a gathering of Black journalists to suggest his election opponent, Kamala Harris, has switched racial identities from Indian to Black.

title.children: Donald Trump suggests Kamala Harris 'happened to turn Black'

image.altText: a windsock hangs limp next to an airport taxiway and runway

props.synopsis: The federal government was late to announce successful recipients of a regional grant program in May and months later its dodging questions about the delivery of funds, as at least one major project faces a significant cost blowout.

title.children: This town was ecstatic when it won federal funding for its airport, but the cash is yet to arrive
